definitions.definition: to feel certain that something is true or that somebody is telling you the truth

examples.text: I don't believe you!
The man claimed to be a social worker and she believed him.
Do you **really believe** her?
Believe me, she's not right for you.
I believed their lies for years.
I find that **hard to believe**.
**Don't believe a word of it** *(= don't believe any part of what somebody is saying)*.
People used to believe (that) the earth was flat.
He refused to believe (that) his son was involved in drugs.
**I do believe** you’re right *(= I think something is true, even though it is surprising)*.
I'm inclined to believe you.
It's hard to believe that this campaign has been going on for ten years.
It was generally believed that evil spirits lived in the forest.
The ad led us to believe (= made us think) that all prices had been cut.

phrases: not believe a word of something

definitions.definition: to think that something is true or possible, although you are not completely certain
definitions.sensetop: believe (that)…it is believed (that)…believe somethingbe believed to be, have, etc. somethingbe believed + adj.

examples.text: ‘Where does she come from?’ ‘Spain, I believe.’
‘Does he still work there?’ ‘I **believe so/not**.’
Police believe (that) the man may be armed.
Experts believe that the diamond is the only one of its kind.
l **firmly believe** that they are still alive.
There is no **reason to believe** he is dangerous.
It is believed that the couple have left the country.
It is **widely believed** that he was forced to resign.
Few people believe the claim that the cost of living has not risen since last year.
The vases are believed to be worth over $20 000 each.
examples.contextForm: be believed to be, have, etc. something

examples.text: Three sailors are missing, believed drowned.
We have reason to believe that the escaped prisoner may be hiding in this house.
No one seriously believes that this war will happen.
Paul says he's happy, but his mother believes otherwise.

definitions.definition: to have the opinion that something is right or true

examples.text: The party believes (that) education is the most important issue facing the government.
She believes that killing animals for food or fur is completely immoral.
I **strongly believe** that competition is a good thing.
She **truly believes** that love can change the world.
I personally believe that it's important.
I've long believed that a good reputation is the most valuable asset you can have in business.
I believe that we have a responsibility towards the less fortunate in society.

phrases: not believe a word of something

definitions.definition: used to say that you are surprised or annoyed at something

examples.text: She couldn’t believe (that) it was all happening again.
I don't believe I'm doing this!
I can't believe how much better I feel.
I couldn't believe what I was hearing.

phrases: not believe a word of something

examples.text: The god appears only to those who believe.

definitions.definition: used to introduce information that is true but that may surprise people

examples.text: Believe it or not, he asked me to marry him!

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that you strongly believe what you are saying

examples.text: You haven't heard the last of this, believe you me!

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that something is definitely not true

examples.text: ‘She wouldn’t do a thing like that.’ ‘Don’t you believe it!’
I was given to understand that she had resigned.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are surprised or annoyed about something

examples.text: I don't believe it! What are you doing here?

definitions.definition: used to say that you think somebody is stupid if they believe that something is true

examples.text: ‘He promised not to do it again.’ ‘Sure, and if you believe that, you’ll believe anything.’

definitions.definition: to pretend that something is true
to be very surprised at something you hear/see

examples.text: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody will have to believe that something is true when they see it, although they do not think it is true now
used to show that you are surprised and annoyed about something

examples.text: And, would you believe, they didn't even apologize!

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that something is definitely true

examples.text: ‘He’s not a bad player, is he?’ ‘You’d better believe it!’

wordOrigin: late Old English belȳfan, belēfan, alteration of gelēfan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch geloven and German glauben.
